section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background and introduce vocabulary (searched, reply).
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking, Why do the animals go to the school?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing vocabulary in context.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Respond appropriately to spoken language; Show understanding of spoken language.
Show an awareness of new words and curiosity about their meaning.
Use regular and irregular past tense.
Identify own body within surroundings and respect others’ personal space.
Focus attention (Self-Regulation).
Use different art materials for exploration and for sensory experience.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Challenge children to identify the different ways that we can reply to someone.
Encourage children to respond in complete sentences.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What do we do at school?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What are the children in the book doing? Are they at school?
Can you act like you’re searching for someone or something?
Can you draw two animals that are looking for Suzy Sue?
What school activities could you write about?
Can you draw something that you do every day at school?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word reply? Can you write the letter?
Can you use blocks to make a shelf for your book?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder show self-awareness and introduce vocabulary (routine, preschool).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to Preschool Time.
Read closely to notice and talk about the Mind Builder.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Respond appropriately to spoken language; Show understanding of spoken language.
Show an awareness of new words and curiosity about their meaning.
Use subject-verb agreement.
Show self-awareness in different or multiple ways.
Explore geography tools and resources, such as maps, signs, and street addresses.
Master basic skills of running, jumping, climbing, and pedaling.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Challenge children to act out different words and sentences from Preschool Time.
Encourage children to use complete sentences to accompany their pantomimes.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What do we do at school?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you show something you do at school?
Pretend you are a preschool teacher. What would you teach?
Name three things that you use at school.
What do you like to do at school? Can you write about it?
Draw a picture of something that you see in your classroom.
Can you name the first letter in the word preschool? Can you think of any words that start with that letter?
Can you build a preschool out of blocks?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Preschool Time by Mij Kelly, illustrated by Mary McQuillan. Text copyright © 2014 by Mij Kelly. Illustrations copyright © 2014 by Mary McQuillan. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Barron’s Educational Series, Inc. section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the comprehension skill Use Background Knowledge and introduce vocabulary (weep, pretend).
Begin Story Time by revisiting Preschool Time and asking, What do the animals learn about Suzy Sue’s preschool?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Respond appropriately to spoken language.
Show an awareness of new words and curiosity about their meaning.
Focus attention (Self-Regulation).
Explore geography tools and resources, such as maps, signs, and street addresses.
Use different art materials for exploration and for sensory experience.
Describe and sort objects by similarities and differences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Have children divide picture cards into “pretend things” and “real things.”
Encourage children to use complete sentences in their speech.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What do we do at school?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How are the characters in the book the same? Different?
Pretend you are a character in the book. Show how you would act.
Look at the characters in the book. Which one is the biggest? How do you know?
Can you write about something that you do every day at preschool?
How many real farm animals have you seen? Can you draw one and color it?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word weep? Can you make that sound?
Can you use blocks to build a farm?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Preschool Time by Mij Kelly, illustrated by Mary McQuillan. Text copyright © 2014 by Mij Kelly. Illustrations copyright © 2014 by Mary McQuillan. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Barron’s Educational Series, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas: Our School Rules

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background on school rules, and introduce vocabulary words (listen, school).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts Preschool Time and Our School Rules.
Read interactively and connect to this week’s concept question, What do we do at school?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: Listening: Respond appropriately to spoken language. Show understanding of spoken language.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Show an awareness of new words and curiosity about their meaning.
Focus attention (Self-Regulation).
Use different art materials for exploration and for sensory experience.
Master basic skills of running, jumping, climbing, and pedaling.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Have children divide picture cards into activities they do at school and activities they do not do at school.
Encourage children to use complete sentences in their conversation and responses.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What do we do at school?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What do you think Suzy Sue’s friends like about preschool? Why?
Pretend to play one of your favorite outdoor games.
Which preschool activities did Suzy Sue’s friends like the best?
Which animal in Preschool Time did you like the most? Can you write about it?
Can you use clay or paper to make or draw the animal you liked the most in Preschool Time?
Can you show me what letter makes the beginning of the word listen? What sound does that letter make?
Can you build a wall out of blocks that you can jump over? Not too high!

Illustrations copyright © 2014 by Mary McQuillan. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Barron’s Educational Series, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to have children act out animal characters and to introduce vocabulary words (spies, disguise).
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking, What do the animals do when they come home?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Respond appropriately to spoken language; Show understanding of spoken language.
Show an awareness of new words and curiosity about their meaning.
Focus attention (Self-Regulation).
Use different art materials for exploration and for sensory experience.

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: Fine Motor: Show emerging proficiency on tasks requiring eye-hand coordination (draw pictures recognizable to child but not others; cut with scissors but may not be able to cut across page.)

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: If you could make a disguise, what would it look like?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What do we do at school?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: If you wrote your own book about school, what would you put in it?
Can you pretend to be the dog searching high and low for Suzy Sue?
Can you work together to name four farm animals? Which is the biggest? Which is the smallest?
Can you create a story about a group with farm animals?
The farm animals made a plan when they came home. Can you make a plan for your home?
The word spies starts with the letter s. Can you find the letter s?
Can you use blocks to build a school for Suzy Sue and her animal friends?

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Show understanding by responding appropriately.
Show understanding of the language being spoken by teachers and peers.
Use regular and irregular plurals, regular past tense, personal and possessive pronouns, and subject-verb agreement.
Are aware of where own body is in space and respects personal boundaries.
Remain focused on engaging group activities for up to 20 minutes at a time.
Use a variety of art materials and activities for sensory experience and exploration.
Show understanding by responding appropriately
Show understanding of the language being spoken by teachers and peers.
Use regular and irregular plurals, regular past tense, personal and possessive pronouns, and subject-verb agreement.
Show self-awareness and can express pride in age-appropriate abilities and skills.
Sustain attention to personally chosen or routine tasks until completed.
Explore geography tools and resources.
Demonstrate coordination and balance in isolation (may not yet coordinate consistently with a partner).
Show understanding by responding appropriately.
Use regular and irregular plurals, regular past tense, personal and possessive pronouns, and subject-verb agreement.
Remain focused on engaging group activities for up to 20 minutes at a time.
Use a variety of art materials and activities for sensory experience and exploration.
Sort objects that are the same and different into groups and use language to describe how the groups are similar and different.
Show understanding by responding appropriately.
Show understanding of the language being spoken by teachers and peers.
Remain focused on engaging group activities for up to 20 minutes at a time.
Use a variety of art materials and activities for sensory experience and exploration.
Sort objects that are the same and different into groups and use language to describe how the groups are similar and different.
Demonstrate coordination and balance in isolation (may not yet coordinate consistently with a partner).
Show understanding by responding appropriately
Show understanding of the language being spoken by teachers and peers.
Sustain attention to personally chosen or routine (teacher-directed) tasks until completed
Remain focused on engaging group activities for up to 20 minutes at a time.
Use a variety of art materials and activities for sensory experience and exploration.
Show increasing control of tasks that require eye-hand coordination.
